'Xylose' (cf. Greek Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Ï, xylos, "wood") is a sugar first isolated from wood,
and named for it. Xylose is classified as a monosaccharide of the aldopentose
type, which means that it contains five carbon atoms and includes a formyl
functional group. It is the precursor to hemicellulose, one of the main
constituents of biomass. Like most sugars, it can adopt several structures
depending on conditions. With its free carbonyl group, it is a reducing sugar.
